structured_info.title_cn: 通过专用交叉口在混合交通中释放网联自动驾驶车辆的二维效益
structured_info.title_en: Unleashing the two-dimensional benefits of connected and automated vehicles via dedicated intersections in mixed traffic
structured_info.abstract: The management of mixed traffic systems is critical to realize the benefits of connected and automated vehicles (CAVs). Generally, the benefits of CAVs can be categorized into the one-dimensional benefits of improving car-following performance and the two-dimensional benefits of efficiently addressing right-of-way conflicts. Researchers have proposed dedicated lanes that can exploit the one-dimensional benefits of CAVs, but the two-dimensional benefits remain unexplored in mixed traffic environments. To fully release the benefits of CAVs, we introduce an innovative approach for managing mixed traffic in road networks, known as the dedicated intersection strategy. Specifically, the dedicated intersection strategy refers to constructing two-dimensional CAV-dedicated right-of-way within the road network, achieving separation between CAVs and human driven vehicles (HDVs) at the intersection level. However, the deployment problem of dedicated intersections is an NP-hard problem. Therefore, we propose a bi-level solving framework, in which the upper level determines the dedicated intersection deployment scheme and the lower level solves the corresponding traffic assignment problem. To quickly find adequate deployment schemes, we propose an artificial bee colony based intelligent algorithm. Our numerical experiments demonstrate that the proposed algorithm can quickly find near-optimal dedicated intersection deployment schemes within a small number of iterations. Compared to regular intersections, the deployment of dedicated intersections in the road network can improve overall traffic system efficiency, particularly for CAVs. Finally, microscopic traffic simulation experiments further verify the superior performance of the proposed dedicated intersection strategy.
structured_info.methodology: Bi-level optimization framework with upper-level dedicated intersection deployment and lower-level user equilibrium traffic assignment, solved using an artificial bee colony algorithm and Frank-Wolfe method.
structured_info.conclusion: Dedicated intersections effectively release the two-dimensional benefits of CAVs through signal-free cooperative driving, significantly improving overall traffic system efficiency (9.12% gain at 50% CAV penetration). The artificial bee colony algorithm efficiently solves the NP-hard deployment problem, and benefits increase with higher CAV penetration rates (>40%).
structured_info.venue: Transportation Research Part C: Emerging Technologies

analysis.Overview: Proposes dedicated intersections to separate CAVs and HDVs at intersections, enabling signal-free cooperative driving for CAVs and improving network-wide traffic efficiency through a bi-level optimization framework.
Background_and_Motivation: Transition to autonomous driving involves a mixed traffic stage where CAV benefits are hindered by HDV uncertainty and randomness.
Existing dedicated lane strategies only address one-dimensional benefits (car-following improvements), failing to resolve two-dimensional right-of-way conflicts at intersections.
Urban network efficiency is dominated by intersection conflicts; cooperative CAV driving can eliminate signals but requires homogeneous CAV environments.
The strategy links specific intersection management to broader challenges of maximizing CAV potential in mixed traffic, establishing significance through capacity/efficiency metrics.
Transportation engineering, optimization algorithms, traffic flow theory.
Conceptual_Framework_and_Innovations: Dedicated Intersection: Intersections exclusively for CAVs using signal-free cooperative driving.
Two-dimensional Benefits: Efficiency gains from resolving spatial conflicts (vs. one-dimensional car-following gains).
Bi-level Optimization: Upper-level deployment + lower-level traffic assignment.
Dedicated intersections enable cooperative driving → improve CAV efficiency → enhance system performance. Deployment decisions affect traffic assignment outcomes.
Perfect CAV-HDV separability; availability of cooperative driving algorithms; user equilibrium behavior.
Introduces a novel traffic management paradigm and solves NP-hard deployment via swarm intelligence, advancing mixed traffic optimization.
Methodology: Bi-level framework: Upper-level deploys intersections (0-1 integer programming); lower-level solves user equilibrium traffic assignment with BPR cost functions.
Artificial bee colony adapted for discrete optimization; Frank-Wolfe for traffic assignment. Novel neighborhood search handles solution space efficiently.
Road network topology (49 nodes, 224 links), link capacities (HDV: 450 vphpl; CAV: 550 vphpl), demand tables. Representativeness validated via microscopic simulation.
Comprehensive sensitivity analysis (penetration rates, asymmetry, density); metrics: system travel time, MFD, individual vehicle delays.
Follows transportation network optimization paradigm, focusing on system optimum and equilibrium principles.
Results: Algorithm finds top-5% solutions in 27.8 min; 9.12% system efficiency gain at 50% CAV penetration; CAV travel time reduced by 15-20%.
Results consistent across network sizes; penetration/density sensitivity follows expected trends; microscopic simulations validate macroscopic gains.
Argumentation_and_Logic: Hierarchical: Problem motivation → formulation → algorithm design → empirical validation.
1) Dedicated lanes insufficient → 2) Dedicated intersections proposed → 3) NP-hard problem → 4) Swarm intelligence solution → 5) Validation.
Strengths: Clear problem decomposition; comprehensive validation. Weaknesses: HDV fairness not fully addressed. Rebuttals: System gains justify HDV detours; enforceability ensures HDV path existence.
Strengths_and_Limitations: First dedicated intersection strategy; efficient algorithm for NP-hard problem; microscopic-macroscopic validation.
Assumes perfect CAV-HDV separation; static demand; no real-time adaptability.
User equilibrium paradigm may not capture stochastic behaviors; system optimum focus may overlook equity.
Academic_Discourse_and_Rhetoric: Positioned as a paradigm shift from lane-based to intersection-based CAV management.
Defines 'two-dimensional benefits' as a key term; technical tone; contrasts with dedicated lanes to highlight innovation.
Cites foundational traffic assignment/CAV studies; uses experimental results to establish authority; motivation emphasizes urgency of mixed traffic solutions.
Conclusions_and_Implications: Dedicated intersections unlock CAVs' 2D benefits; algorithm efficiently solves deployment; strategy boosts system efficiency (>40% CAV penetration).
Study fairness impacts; dynamic deployment; integration with real-time control; stability analysis in congested networks.
